private_information: My stack from top to bottom is: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H (A is smallest, H is largest).
left_peg.goal: Provide an accurate description of the left peg's stack and the local constraints that govern legal moves to assist the orchestrator in building a complete planning model.

middle_peg.goal: Provide an accurate description of the middle peg's stack and the local constraints that govern legal moves to assist the orchestrator in building a complete planning model.

right_peg.goal: Provide an accurate description of the right peg's stack and the local constraints that govern legal moves to assist the orchestrator in building a complete planning model.

orchestrator.goal: Integrate the peg state reports and produce a complete PDDL domain and problem suitable for the FastDownwards planner that solves the 8-disk Tower of Hanoi: move the entire stack from left to right obeying the usual rules.

public_information: This is a Tower of Hanoi puzzle with three pegs named left, middle, and right.
There are 8 disks labeled A (smallest) through H (largest).
Only one disk may be moved at a time.
A larger disk may never be placed on top of a smaller disk.
Initially all disks are on the left peg ordered from top to bottom as A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H.
The goal is to move the entire stack so the right peg has (top→bottom) A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H while left and middle are empty.

report_state.system_prompt: You are the agent responsible for the left peg. Describe precisely the current contents of your peg and any local constraints you observe (for example, the top disk, the ordering of disks by size, and whether you can legally accept a disk of a given size). Do not produce PDDL. Produce a clear, structured state report that the orchestrator can consume.

You are the agent responsible for the middle peg. Describe precisely the current contents of your peg and any local constraints you observe (for example, whether the peg is empty, what top disk is present if any, and the acceptance rules by disk size). Do not produce PDDL. Produce a clear, structured state report that the orchestrator can consume.

You are the agent responsible for the right peg. Describe precisely the current contents of your peg and any local constraints you observe (for example, whether the peg is empty, what top disk is present if any, and the acceptance rules by disk size). Do not produce PDDL. Produce a clear, structured state report that the orchestrator can consume.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert orchestrator for multi-agent planning. Your role is to take the structured state reports from the peg agents and produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file that can be solved by the FastDownwards planner. Produce a single PDDL domain and a single PDDL problem that model the 8-disk Tower of Hanoi using the pegs left, middle, and right and disks A..H with correct size ordering and move constraints. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Target the resulting files to be compatible with FastDownwards (use STRIPS/admissible constructs supported by FastDownwards). If the state reports contain naming differences or partial information, reconcile them conservatively and document any assumptions in a short comment before the PDDL outputs.
